an4.61:1.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
an4.61:2.1: “Householder, these four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable are hard to get in the world.
an4.61:2.3: The first thing is the wish: ‘May wealth come to me by legitimate means!’
an4.61:3.1: The second thing, having got wealth by legitimate means, is the wish: ‘May fame come to me, together with my family and teachers.’
an4.61:4.1: The third thing, having got wealth and fame, is the wish: ‘May I live long, keeping alive for a long time!’
an4.61:5.1: The fourth thing, having got wealth, fame, and long life, is the wish: ‘When my body breaks up, after death, may I be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’
an4.61:5.2: These are the four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.
an4.61:6.1: These next four things lead to the getting of those four things.
an4.61:6.3: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.
an4.61:7.1: And what is accomplishment in faith?
an4.61:7.2: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
an4.61:7.3: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an4.61:7.4: This is called accomplishment in faith.
an4.61:8.1: And what is accomplishment in ethics?
an4.61:8.2: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
an4.61:8.3: This is called accomplishment in ethics.
an4.61:9.1: And what is accomplishment in generosity?
an4.61:9.2: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
an4.61:9.3: This is called accomplishment in generosity.
an4.61:10.1: And what is accomplishment in wisdom?
an4.61:10.2: When your heart is mastered by covetousness and immoral greed, you do what you shouldn’t, and fail to do what you should.
an4.61:10.3: Your fame and happiness fall to dust.
an4.61:10.4: When your heart is mastered by ill will …
an4.61:10.10: doubt, you do what you shouldn’t, and fail to do what you should.
an4.61:10.11: Your fame and happiness fall to dust.
an4.61:11.1: Knowing that ‘covetousness and immoral greed are corruptions of the mind’, that noble disciple gives them up.
an4.61:11.5: ‘doubt is a corruption of the mind’, that noble disciple gives it up.
an4.61:12.1: When a noble disciple has given up these things,
an4.61:12.6: they’re called ‘a noble disciple of great wisdom, of widespread wisdom, who sees what matters, and is accomplished in wisdom’.
an4.61:12.7: This is called accomplishment in wisdom.
an4.61:12.8: These are the four things that lead to the getting of the four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.
an4.61:13.1: There are four fitting deeds that a noble disciple does with the legitimate wealth he has earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.
an4.61:13.3: To start with, with his legitimate wealth he makes himself happy and pleased, keeping himself properly happy.
an4.61:13.4: He makes his mother and father happy …
an4.61:13.5: He makes his children, partners, bondservants, workers, and staff happy …
an4.61:13.6: He makes his friends and colleagues happy …
an4.61:13.7: This is his first expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:14.1: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he defends himself against threats from such things as fire, flood, rulers, bandits, or unloved heirs.
an4.61:14.3: This is his second expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:15.1: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes five spirit-offerings:
an4.61:15.2: to relatives, guests, ancestors, king, and deities.
an4.61:15.3: This is his third expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:16.1: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he establishes an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins—those who refrain from intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves—that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
an4.61:16.2: This is his fourth expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:17.1: ’these are the four fitting deeds that a noble disciple does with the legitimate wealth he has earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.
an4.61:17.2: Whatever wealth is spent on something other than these four fitting deeds is said to not be expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:17.3: But whatever wealth is spent on these four fitting deeds is said to be expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.
an4.61:18.1: ‘I’ve enjoyed my wealth, <j>supporting those who depend on me;
an4.61:18.5: I have served the ethical and
an4.61:19.4: I don’t regret what I’ve done.’
an4.61:20.1: A mortal man who recollects this
an4.61:20.2: stands firm in the teaching of the noble ones.
an4.61:20.4: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”
